Standard_Text: Compose simple shapes to form larger shapes.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components (e.g., sticks and clay balls) and drawing shapes.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Analyze and compare two- and three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, differences, parts (e.g., number of sides and vertices/"corners") and other attributes (e.g., having sides of equal length).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Analyze, compare, create, and compose shapes.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify shapes as two-dimensional (lying in a plane, "flat") or three-dimensional ("solid").
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Correctly name shapes regardless of their orientations or overall size.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Describe objects in the environment using names of shapes, and describe the relative positions of these objects using terms such as above, below, beside, in front of, behind, and next to.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify and describe shapes (squares, circles, triangles, rectangles, hexagons, cubes, cones, cylinders, and spheres).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Geometry
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Classify objects into given categories; count the numbers of objects in each category and sort the categories by count.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Classify objects and count the number of objects in each category.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Directly compare two objects with a measurable attribute in common, to see which object has "more of"/"less of" the attribute, and describe the difference.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Describe measurable attributes of objects, such as length or weight. Describe several measurable attributes of a single object.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Describe and compare measurable attributes.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Measurement and Data
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Compose and decompose numbers from 11 to 19 into ten ones and some further ones, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each composition or decomposition by a drawing or equation (e.g., 18 = 10 + 8); understand that these numbers are composed of ten ones and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Work with numbers 11—19 to gain foundations for place value.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Number and Operations in Base Ten
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Fluently add and subtract within 5.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: For any number from 1 to 9, find the number that makes 10 when added to the given number, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record the answer with a drawing or equation.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Decompose numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in more than one way, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each decomposition by a drawing or equation (e.g., 5 = 2 + 3 and 5 = 4 + 1).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Solve addition and subtraction word problems, and add and subtract within 10, e.g., by using objects or drawings to represent the problem.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Represent addition and subtraction with objects, fingers, mental images, drawings, sounds (e.g., claps), acting out situations, verbal explanations, expressions, or equations.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand addition as putting together and adding to, and understand subtraction as taking apart and taking from.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Operations and Algebraic Thinking
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Compare two numbers between 1 and 10 presented as written numerals.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify whether the number of objects in one group is greater than, less than, or equal to the number of objects in another group, e.g., by using matching and counting strategies.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Compare numbers.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Count to answer "how many?" questions about as many as 20 things arranged in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a scattered configuration; given a number from 1—20, count out that many objects.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand that each successive number name refers to a quantity that is one larger.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand that the last number name said tells the number of objects counted. The number of objects is the same regardless of their arrangement or the order in which they were counted.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: When counting objects, say the number names in the standard order, pairing each object with one and only one number name and each number name with one and only one object.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect counting to cardinality.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Count to tell the number of objects.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Count forward beginning from a given number within the known sequence (instead of having to begin at 1).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Count to 100 by ones and by tens.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Know number names and the count sequence.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Counting and Cardinality
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Look for and express regularity in repeated reasoning.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Look for and make use of structure.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Attend to precision.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Use appropriate tools strategically.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Model with mathematics.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Construct viable arguments and critique the reasoning of others.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Reason abstractly and quantitatively.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Make sense of problems and persevere in solving them.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Standards for Mathematical Practice
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify and apply a variety of math­ematical strategies to solve problems in their environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children expand the use of mathematical thinking to solve problems that arise in their everyday environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: At around 60 months of age:
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Begin to apply simple mathematical strategies to solve problems in their environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Mathematical Reasoning
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify positions of objects and people in space, including in/on/ under, up/down, inside/outside, beside/between, and in front/behind.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children expand their understanding of positions in space.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Combine different shapes to create a picture or design.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify, describe, and construct a variety of different shapes, including variations of a circle, triangle, rect­ angle, square, and other shapes.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children identify and use a variety of shapes in their everyday environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: At around 60 months of age:
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify positions of objects and people in space, such as in/on/ under, up/down, and inside/outside.

Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text:
Use individual shapes to represent different elements of a picture
or design.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify simple two-dimensional shapes, such as a circle and square.
Subject: Mathematics

Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: At around 48 months of age:
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Geometry
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Measure length using multiple duplicates of the same-size concrete units laid end to end.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Order four or more objects by size.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text:
Compare two objects by length, weight, or capacity directly
(e.g., putting objects side by side) or indirectly (e.g., using a third object).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children expand their understanding of comparing, ordering, and measuring objects.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: At around 60 months of age:
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Order three objects by size.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Demonstrate awareness that objects can be compared by length, weight, or capacity, by noting gross differences, using words such as bigger, longer, heavier, or taller, or by placing objects side by side to compare length.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children begin to compare and order objects.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: At around 48 months of age:
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Measurement
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Begin to extend and create simple repeating patterns.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Recognize and duplicate simple repeating patterns.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children expand their understanding of simple, repeating patterns.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Sort and classify objects by one or more attributes, into two or more groups, with increasing accuracy (e.g., may sort  rst by one attribute and then by another attribute).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text:
Children expand their understanding of sorting
and classifying objects in their everyday environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: At around 60 months of age
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Attempt to create a simple repeating pattern or participate in making one.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Begin to identify or recognize a simple repeating pattern.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children begin to recognize simple, repeating patterns.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Sort and classify objects by one attribute into two or more groups, with increasing accuracy.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text:
Children begin to sort
and classify objects in their everyday environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: At around 48 months of age
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Algebra and Functions (Classification and Patterning)
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Solve simple addition and subtrac­ tion problems with a small number of objects (sums up to 10), usually by counting.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand that putting two groups of objects together will make a bigger group and that a group of objects can be taken apart into smaller groups.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand that adding one or taking away one changes the number in a small group of objects by exactly one.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Compare, by counting or matching, two groups of up to  ve objects and communicate, “more,” “same as,” or “fewer” (or “less”).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children expand their under­ standing of number relation­ ships and operations in their everyday environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand, when counting, that the number name of the last object counted represents the total number of objects in the group (i.e., cardinality).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text:
Count up to ten objects, using one-to-one correspondence
(one object for each number word) with increasing accuracy.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify, without counting, the number of objects in a collection of up to four objects (i.e., subitize).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Recognize and know the name of some written numerals.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Recite numbers in order to twenty with increasing accuracy.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children expand their under­ standing of numbers and quantities in their everyday environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: At around 60 months of age:
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Solve simple addition and subtrac­ tion problems nonverbally (and often verbally) with a very small number of objects (sums up to 4 or 5).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand that putting two groups of objects together will make a bigger group.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Understand that adding to (or taking away) one or more objects from a group will increase (or decrease) the number of objects in the group.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Compare visually (with or without counting) two groups of objects that are obviously equal or nonequal and communicate, “more” or “same.”
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children begin to understand number relationships and operations in their everyday environment.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Use the number name of the last object counted to answer the question, “How many . . . ?”
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Count up to five objects, using one-to-one correspondence (one object for each number word) with increasing accuracy.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Identify, without counting, the number of objects in a collection of up to three objects (i.e., subitize).
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Begin to recognize and name a few written numerals.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Recite numbers in order to ten with increasing accuracy.
Subject: Mathematics

Standard_Text: Children begin to understand numbers and quantities in their everyday environment.
Subject: Mathematics
